body:
For what it's worth, we actually added this assertion back into our rails project after it was deprecated, since assert_valid displays the validation errors, while assert @model.valid? just displays '<false> should be true.', which is totally unhelpful. Sure, you can stuff those into the 'message' parameter, but then you're typing "Model should be valid: #{@model.errors.full_messages.join('\n')}" every time you try to assert the validity of a model, which you'll eventually DRY into a custom assertion method.

Not that I'd necessarily want Rails to provide it, but I can see why this particular custom assertion would be useful.
